content:
@java_coffee_cup, do you have any concern regarding the draft contribution "Cylinders II"? https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/974318d1c4b3426fd9339d689aa758f7b6e93

The first four pairs of cases there are exactly the same as the ones here.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good one.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a nice geometry problem.

I would like to approve this puzzle, however I cannot produce a solution in the time-constraints. I am using Python and e.g. for testcase #05 I need 13s.  I have looked through your solution. As far as I understand your code the Perm-class does produce every permutation. There is no optimization done to exclude some permutations. So it is essentially a brute-force approach? Also In the calc-method I can't find anything which looks like an optimizing trick.  Does it all come down to the difference in speed between java and python or do I miss something?

hi
i'm struggling with the 1st testcase "example":
the setup with 7 cylinders: expected overall width is 2163.508.
My code finds a solution width length of 1834.377 (using the cylinders in following order: [10, 135, 380, 150, 93, 542, 3]

i dunno, but the smaller result seems to be good for me. is there an error? or my code is wrong somehow...

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: is good

"The diagram in the banner shows an example how ...."
The diagram referred to is not visible in competition mode!

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
Not in the timeframe of CoC - unless you know the math fully beforehand. I think most people dont.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think this is good

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's good

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment:

worked on this for awhile, got some good answers and some bad.  I'm guessing the bad numbers are due to cylinder overlap.  it would seem the adjustment involves an (O2) check on all permutations. Is there a better way?

* The stub generator does not always generate a default code with "N" as the variable name. For example, the python code converts it to "n". To avoid confusion, in Input and Constraints sections, instead of [[N]] and [[n]] it is better to use [[N]] and some other name (e.g. [[m]]) instead.

* Suggest rewording to be more precise:
(a) Given an array "of radii" of cylinders (etc)
(b) The numbers are space separated with "the radii in" no special order. [because the numbers include "the number of cylinders" too]
(c) You just need to care about how all the "cylinders can be packed together tightly to the minimum width by considering the radii only".

Thanks.

You can clarify that cylinders should be packet like on puzzle banner, this image tells a lot.
Especially mark the box edge, you ask for as a result

Technically cylinders have height (you typed length)

'radi' typo
Thanks for your ideas. Implemented.
Thank you spotting the issues. Fixed and improved.

Not necessarily all.
You can skip some of them - repeating values, LR mirrors
Who said CoC?

You may have some cylinders overlapping in your ordering.
To verify it visually, you can write a simple js code using canvas to display the circles. You need every circle's center (x,y) and r.

In my experience Java and python are similarly slow, a lot slower than C or C++.  If a java program can do it in a split second python should also be able to do it.

I intentionally choose a non-optimized brute-force approach in the solution. I guess if this one works, other optimized approach should work even better.

Needing over 10 sec to solve one test case is more likely a problem with the coding more than about the language. I suggest you set some timers in your program to find out which functional part uses the most processing time. Then you can focus on that inefficient part to improve.

Thanks for notifying. The appearing of "Cylinders II" is really a concern. The statement, test case, banner are mostly copycats. The given solution is encrypted no one knows.... I would downvote it for its unoriginality and wish others would do so.

There are many existing puzzles that i think my solution can outperform 1000 times than the max constraints but I would never copy them and extend the constraint to become a version II. I might share an extreme test case as a challenge in forum if people are interested in improving algorithm design. 

I, as a puzzle solver, am not interested in seeing or solving duplicates puzzles. I think having this kind of duplicates is a pollution to the uniqueness of the puzzle collections.
Would you please consider leaving a comment in that contribution? As you're the original author, your comment will carry much more weight than anybody else's.
Indeed a proper approach.
This is good advice. I tried hard. Sadly, I failed. I need 0.7s for a box with 8 cylinders and 8s for a box with 9 cylinders. It's a pity, because I like the geometry in this problem.
I translated my Python code line by line to Java. It worked now within the time-constraints.
Wonderful. Interesting to know which imported library in py caused the lag.
